title: Can we change nullifying orb to also block physical damage?
body: My understanding is that the sorcery tree is supposed to be dedicated to spell damage, so why not change nullifying orb from blocking solely magic damage to blocking physical damage AND magic damage but from spells only? This would be consistent with the theme of the tree, make the mastery useful to mages who are laning against physical damage opponents while also broadening the usefulness of the mastery for those who wish to protect themselves against magic damage burst only.

(Above is hyperbolic, so ignore it and let's do real math)

Let's take Annie, pre vs post runes (values at 28 and 19 respectively) using your 200 damage analogy. Ignoring any abilities and penetration because your set value is 200 damage.

28 armor = 78% incoming physical damage; 156 

19 armor = 84% incoming physical damage; 168

You take 12 more damage. The 40 HP increase is much more significant AND helps you against magic damage too. 

Now if you want to point out that "well we could've ran (suboptimal) full armor" then sure, but in terms of the compensation you were so snarkily commenting about, it's been accounted for. Does this mean it doesn't warrant buffs? No. But you've gained more.

The thing is that Armor is specifically a stat meant to buffer your "entire" hp pool. Saying "oh armor makes this 200 of my 900 HP worth less than 36* flat HP" is inherently slanting the issue, because armor applies to your entire HP pool, and your pots, and your shields/Spellvamp (if your midlaner has shields/Spellvamp).

There's simply no way to slice it such that 9 Armor is worth less than 36 HP against AD enemies. Even 48 is "less than veteran scars" territory.

*changed 40 to 36 to reflect an actual multiple of 12

We can, but I don't think we should. We had iterations of nullifying orb that were much more inclusive, and they very quickly became mandatory. This left us with the options of either restricting the Rune to be more situational or remove it. I believe it's important for a number of mages to have a way to plan for a lane where the range disparity against other mages is a defining element of the early game, so I would prefer we don't remove the option outright. When we tested weaker general versions of the rune, it stopped being understandable. Shields that pop in reaction to damage tend to get crushed by the incoming damage, and this is especially true at small values. 

That being said, I know physical assassins are a constant source of consternation on these boards, and we have seen that this is even more pronounced since 7.22 dropped. We always expect balance to be a bit rocky after changes this large, and we're definitely knee deep in the chaotic, unoptimized state right now. You're likely to see some small nudges to individual runes or champions for the next patch or two as we let some of the dust settle. 

If I could make one small suggestion, there are a number of us watching the boards right now, looking to talk about the state of the game and Runes in general. This can be really hard on gameplay boards because of the exceptionally negative hyperbole that tends to be so prevalent. It doesn't help that dissenting opinions are also frequently downvoted into oblivion (as there are a few examples even in this thread). I personally love to talk to players and do so on a lot of different platforms, but boards is sadly one of the most draining. I figured it might be worth pointing out that we'd really love to talk on here a lot more about Runes, if folks are open to having actual discussions.
But even when I ask nicely no one wants to talk about Viktor. :'(

Sometimes we just don't have much news about a given champion. We do often have to default to being quiet until we have something real we can discuss. It doesn't feel good from our side, but setting expectations only to crush them later is even worse if an exploration doesn't go well.

I've expressed this opinion before but since you're here and talking to us I'll bring it up again.

> "We had iterations of nullifying orb that were much more inclusive, and they very quickly became mandatory."

If you ask the question "when do I take this rune?" and the answer is  "it is mandatory in too many matchups" taking away matchups in which its mandatory without changing why it's mandatory doesn't make the design of the rune any better and doesn't create interesting or compelling choices about the rune. If the rune is necessary against Diana and Talon or Lux and Jayce making it so it doesn't work against Talon and Jayce doesn't make it a better or more interesting or more compelling rune, it just means that you have fewer options against Talon and Jayce.

> "I believe it's important for a number of mages to have a way to plan for a lane where the range disparity against other mages is a defining element of the early game, so I would prefer we don't remove the option outright. 

If range is the issue you were trying to solve why did you address burst damage not range? (60 second cooldown triggering on dropping low makes the rune much more powerful against burst than any other sort of damage) Part of the reason players want this rune to work against Talon, Zed, etc. is that it is very well designed to defend against those champions while it is poorly designed to defend against iterative poke (which is spaced out more evenly meaning less of the impact will be negated by the shield and more of the shield is likely to be wasted). 

> "When we tested weaker general versions of the rune, it stopped being understandable. Shields that pop in reaction to damage tend to get crushed by the incoming damage, and this is especially true at small values."

If the versions weren't balanced properly (were too weak) then bringing them in in a discussion of the design of the rune when properly balanced isn't hugely relevant. If on the other hand these versions of the rune were the balanced version (which I am guessing is what you are trying to say though I'm reading between the lines a bit here) then what you've just expressed is that the rune has comprehension issues when balanced properly which is an inherent problem with the design, NOT an incentive to balance it improperly to fix the comprehension issues (which, if you were trying to talk about the balance of the rune, is what you have done). 

I understand that just complaining doesn't actually help you solve any issues so I'd like to offer a few different solutions and discuss their merits.

1) Remove the rune and replace it with another option: If the rune is as binary as you have said it is then it's not a real option, it's a false choice (like old runes) that players either make correctly and get to play the game or make incorrectly and lose an extra N% of the time because they didn't do a bunch of research outside of the game. If you believe that's the case then the rune should be removed, false choices aren't fun or interesting, they're just bad design. Unfortunately the downside here is that you no longer have a solution to the problem Nulifying Orb was trying to solve so you have to come up with a new solution. This takes design time and resources as well as art assets so this is likely the most costly and slowest solution.

2) Make the rune not care about the damage type: If the rune is basically fine as is and is an acceptable strategic option against Lux or Diana then making it available as a strategic option against Jayce and Zed shouldn't be a problem. This is a very easy solution to implement though it carries balance implications down the road. This does add unintended extra tankyness when taking mixed damage after lane which might add a lot of hidden power. On the other hand it takes significantly less time and resources as it is a very small change.

3) Add a new rune without removing nulifying orb which is functionally identical except it only triggers from physical damage: If the rune is fine for lane matchups but adds unnecessary extra tankyness against mixed damage later in the game then allowing a similar option against AD champions shouldn't be a problem and by keeping it to only defending against one damage type you avoid some of the lategame blowback of just generalized tankyness. I imagine that in time and resources this is a middle of the road approach because a lot of the work from Nullifying Orb can be reused but you still need to make art assets and change the layout of the rune tree.

TLDR: there are better approaches to nullifying orb than the one in game, I think it should be replaced or changed, but there are a lot of different ways it could be changed.

> I believe it's important for a number of mages to have a way to plan for a lane where the range disparity against other mages is a defining element of the early game, so I would prefer we don't remove the option outright. 

The thing is, that I don't believe that anybody is picking Nullifying Orb for these cases. If anything, I think it's more common to see Manaflow Band in that case so you can just outshove. Where people do pick Nullifying Orb tends to be in matchups where you're at risk of being all-in'd, i.e. against AP assassins or burst mages. This cuts down on their power considerably since they tend to rely on snowballing to hit their one-shot benchmarks later in the game, while long range mages in mid don't really care as much if they get denied a kill or two in laning phase.

So, if the intention is to have a rune to stymie burst champions from snowballing, that's fine, but I don't see any reason it shouldn't apply equally to AD and AP. If anything, I would argue it should apply solely to AD damage since they tend to have the tools to finish off champions who don't die in one rotation (auto-attacks), while AP burst champs don't tend to have that sort of fallback pattern. If a hypothetical physical version of Nullifying Orb gives you enough HP to survive a Zed rotation, he can risk himself somewhat to throw in an extra auto-attack or two. In contrast, if Nullifying Orb gives you enough HP to survive a Fizz rotation, you probably just walk away and recall.

If the intention is really to introduce parity between casters of differing ranges, then I would say that Nullifying Orb does a poor job of it.

Assassins do not need to be weaker, they do not need to lower their burst any more than it already is. At this point, as a player, I see very little difference between divers and assassins. They get to one person, they take some time to kill that one person, and that's it. Assassins have a better likelihood of getting out, divers have a little more beef to them. Their ultimate roles are exactly the same and that is frustrating to me as a player. I would rather have assassins be interesting and unique and frustrating to play against than I would for them to become just divers that have to build full AD.

And how do you propose Riot nerf them?
AA's are the game's most effective damage system. ADC or not.
AA's are the only way to damage structures. ADC or not.
Ranged is ~~better~~ safer than melee. ADC or not.
These are all ***core*** game-play elements that combine to ensure ADC's are the most valuable class. And that's why you can't just nerf them and expect the entire meta to reshuffle.

You can nerf their durability, but the support will still be there to save their ass. You can nerf itemization, but they've demonstrated many times their ability to abuse damn near anything (Tank Vayne, AP Kog, Pen Jhin, Juggernaut Graves, <item> Ezreal, etc.). You can remove their survivability *and* Support (champion) Support (capacity) until they both become a liability; but now you've just removed two entire roles from the game.

Fixing the problem isn't as simple as "nerf ADC." We have to fix the core elements that make them so valuable.

These changes would nerf *all* ADC's. Because the game will still revolve around them, the role's win rate will barely flinch.
